positive.review:
So right off the bat the game is rough around the edges. 
Graphics - feel like they are really outdated though they make it look amazing in videos and artwork. If you are someone that can tolerate a slightly outdated feel then go for it.
Performance - has improved quite alot since launch, less laggy and buggy, though towns have serious FPS drops as well as if you are in your house for some reason. 
Enemies and story these really aren't the main focus, enemies re-spawn and are static for the most part. If you have played black dessert or any such game you will know what am talking about. This has potential in other areas, the loot and rewards you get from boss battles, Arenas, PVE and PVP battles, Ranking system they all feel like i want to come back., they feel like they carry weight. The farming and breeding of animals and a live market system all make it a game worth trying. 

in short - rough around the edges, not the best looking, but if you can overlook some of these aspects and love MMORPG mechanics you will really enjoy this game.

This game has huge potential! It's a fully fleshed out MMO Sandbox with lots and lots to do and a huge, beautiful world to explore. The devs are very active and making updates and patches often and they listen to the player base, which is refreshing. 
That being said, it's early access and still has lots of bugs and is a bit grindy for my taste. I hope they get everything fixed and balanced because I'd like to go back and play at some point. 
If you don't mind a grind and dealing with bugs, you'll probably like this game.

Considering it's still a work in progress, I have to say it has just about everything I could want in an MMO. Since the devs said there's not going to be a wipe it's worth playing while they polish this out.  It's got more content then ashes and pantheon and even released pax. From a PVE only perspective it's great, couldn't tell you about PVP, I don't care for that in any game.

This is the most fun I have had on an MMO in a very long time! The DEV team are responsive and a great group. The Community is great and growing by the day. I love the mechanics. Map is huge. Tweaks and updates are frequent. The bones of this game are shaping up to be on par with AAA mmorpg. The map is huge! There are both idle and active mechanics. I can't say enough.

A really fulfilling game, so much to do and such a bright future ahead of it. It is in Development so it is not finished but I love their direction and their communication with players in Out of This World !!! Cannot say enough nice things about them and I pray they succeed in all their Plans. Wonderful Company !!! Breath of Fresh air !!!

Really like the game. I know once it ready it will ne a 10/10 game for sure.  Mounts, boats, farming, then actual farm land. The game play is cool but still in first phase. The game should get better over time once its fully ready.

Really fun Game ! Lots to do and a fun world. A mix of Black Desert Online and other MMOs. They really got creative and added every element they could into the game. I think they have something here... !!!

Best MMORPG ever, i like classic medieval, no power ranger armor and weapons. Good work system. No pay to win. Nice configuration like the character size customize and graphics. I liked so much this game.
not bad better with each update needs better control remapping

Form your own opinion!  ~  This game is great, super addicting. Has more under the hood then 90% of MMO's out there. The grind is unorthodox and enjoyable, the market is completely player run and quite volatile even with the average steam charts player counts being 1,000 -/+ nightly.
Feels like playing a seamless blend of some of the best games in the genre but somehow the amalgamation is not a mishmash and feels properly interwoven.
Devz are actively updating the game and optimizing. I have steered completely clear of what other's have said about this game because it does seem they were promised one thing as an early access and the release wasn't up to par in their eyes. Still I can't help but speak for how complex and layered the many interdependencies of this games systems and economy make it what New World should have been and more.
Check it out for yourself!

This game is actually quite good! I bought the game at launch and played for a month or so, took a break for a bit and came back a little while ago and I have seen HUGE improvements in the game! It is one of the largest game worlds I think that I've ever seen, and it's FULL of content and things to explore! Open world bosses to conquer, open world dungeons, instanced dungeons, treasure chests scattered all throughout the world to find as well as treasure rooms with even more loot, TONS of professions and trade skills to master, in depth and intricate crafting system, and even the potential to build a home!! This game is LOADED with things to do, and TONS of different ways to play and enjoy the game! Very active and engaging community as well! The PVP in this game is also fantastic! There's open world PVP to be had as well as actual PVP matches like capture the flag, conquest, kill count, etc. This game is not developed by a huge team/studio, and yet even still, they have managed to create a VERY lively game world to explore in one of the most difficult genres to create a game within! On top of all of that, they are INCREDIBLY engaging with their player base and the community in regards to bug notices, suggestions, complaints, Q&A, and anything else! Many of the updated changes that have come to the game ever since launch have in fact been suggestions made by the very player base! This game deserves recognition, and this game has IMMENSE potential in becoming something even more magical and amazing than it already is now in early access! I don't write reviews very often, but this game TRULY deserves the positive feedback, as it has certainly earned that feedback in my eyes. This game has SO much to see and do and explore and adventure, that you will NEVER find yourself with nothing to do. It reminds me a lot of OSRS (Old School Runescape) in the way there are so many different trade skills and professions to master and level up, but modernized with better graphics and MUCH more engaging combat! Speaking of which, the combat is fantastic as well! It is a fantastic blend of action combat with tab targeting in regards to using spells from your hotbar while also "auto attacking" (holding left click). The game is so full of content and things to do, and they're just getting started! I think I'll be here for a while, and I greatly look forward to the future of The Quinfall ^_^

The Qunifall plays like a MMO of old. There are huge grinds to achieve the goals of progress. In some cases, it might not be for the feint of heart. However, if you are willing to put in the time to progress, what you will find in this game is a community of players, devs, and community service managers willing to help you if you reach out to them and put forth the effort on your own. It doesn't mean your ever request will be granted by any of them, but my experience has been great. If you are polite and try, eventually someone will answer those questions, help you level, group up with you, and invite you to their clan. Technically speaking our group is small, and we haven't went out of our way to interact outside of our current clan and small group of friends. What I can say, is the few times I have, it was certainly met with kind, helpful individuals. Like any game in today's world, I suspect you'll encounter the occasional troll, but there is really no avoiding that. I have watched the devs and their community service listen to the player base, I've also had amazing experiences with the few times I've needed to put in a ticket on their discord for in game issues. The Quinfall reminds me so much of the challenge, grind, and community I missed so much from my early days of playing EverQuest. Several of our group have really been enjoying what The Quinfall has to offer, and I am certainly looking forward to watching it grow and what other changes, challenges, and adventures it might have to offer.

As of 10/18/25, I've only played Quinfall for almost 5 hours.
I have to say that despite how much grief this game has gotten - which is pretty valid since this game has some bugs, glitches, and issues that need addressing - it's still a pretty decent game overall.

The combat system is great. It's very modern and up to date with some of the combat moves I've seen in other games recently.
However, it doesn't feel smooth or realistic. The turning is too fast, sudden, and janky. The lock-on system isn't 100% accurate and some of the attacks for the dual-wield axes need some work or at least not feel so Black Desert Online in design.
Maybe if the developers look towards Assassin's Creed Valhalla and Guild Wars 2 for inspiration on that, it would maybe be better in the long run.
The gathering of resources is great, there's some glitching with the tree meshes and textures when they transition from 3 dots to 2 dots. But i'm not sure if this is just me or something else entirely.
I'm not sure if we can use the resources we gather to build our very own house or claim a territory like we can in Once Human. But if we can, that would be fantastic since I love resource gathering and building when i can and if's an option.
Another thing that I would like to see is possibly some voice acting. At least for the major quest-giving NPC's and maybe our player character making comments/observations of the world as they explore it. Full-fledged cutscenes? No. For that, i will play my BioWare and Witcher games and call it done.

My number one pet peeve about this game is this - the textures and meshes are not optimized as well as they should be. And there are some graphical assets that need adjusting to make it easier for those on lower-end PC's to possibly play the game too.
I'm not saying this to be whiny or anything. My desktop gaming PC meets the minimum and recommended specs for Quinfall and yet I'm only getting an average of 20FPS *maximum* in *ALL* areas of the starter zone so far at level 29. And that is been a problem for me on medium, high, ultra, and epic graphical settings.
For those who are curious about my specs:
AMD Ryzen 7 8700F 8-Core Processor (4.10 GHz)
Nvidia Geforce RTX 5090 Ti (8GB vram) graphics card
16GB DDR5 RAM
1920x1080 native resolution via TV screen w/VSync turned on
If the devs can do what they can with the engine they're using to fully optimize their textures, meshes, and everything else, that would be fantastic. Because I should not be getting only 20FPS when I should be getting at least twice that while playing the game.

Despite my own personal issues with my game/playthrough, Quinfall has a lot of potential to be a great MMORPG or multplayer game in general.
It's still in it's early access phase, so there is a lot of room for improvement until the devs are confident and comfortable enough to release Quinfall in it's 100% entirety.
I'm leaving this as a thumb's up for now because of that. and I hope that this review helps any others that are looking to play Quinfall for the first time like myself :).

I am impressed with the variety of housing options from instanced to not. I hope they continue to improve this game, it's definitely not a finished polished product yet.

The translation system in the game is nice as no matter your language it seems to translate for others of other languages supported by the system.

Okay, so I want you to keep in mind that this game is early access.

The graphics are relatively polished, but I will say that frame rate drops as you *lower* the detail settings, which is weird.  The sound's pretty decent, but I turn off the music so I can't gauge that.

The people on the PvE servers are super friendly, but you will see some convivial shit-talking amongst the PvP-ers.

The arena for PvP is currently a little dead.

I am a hoarder and sorter in MMO's.  I like gathering, crafting, killing enemies and accumulating wealth.  

The game doesn't really have a fully fleshed-out loot table system yet.  They're still working on it from what I can tell.

They've set up a loot drop system for fishing and an afk system for the same gathering profession, but not for any others. 

The crafting, from what I can tell, can ALL be done AFK and you get experience for each thing that you're doing as long as you're within proximity to the crafting station, and if you have an altar set up (real easy to get), you get xp from that as well.

My real, HUGE main beef with anything in this game is - while you can remap damn near all keys - you cannot remap INTERACT.

I'm a traditionalist that was raised whenever keyboards were being established (yeah, I'm old).  I use ESDF like both God AND Satan intended, bless both of their souls.

Before anyone responds to, "Just use WASD, it's what every other game uses".  No it doesn't.  Damn near all games have that as a default, sure, but if they allow you to remap keys, they have the forethought to allow remapping of the interact key.

Imagine being in a PvP arena and you have a flower near the enemy, but you're trying to roll past them and instead you just start picking up the flower.

Now, realize that there are gatherable things EVERYWHERE.

Imagine how many things are stopping you from dodging or even moving at all.  (Apparently the 'F' key is also a secondary interact, so moving right also does the same thing).

Towns are full of interactable NPCs, but I can't get to the merchant 'cause a kid is walking by and I start talking to her.  I can only move left using 'S' or backwards using 'D'.

Every day, I'm shufflin' (to the left).

That's my biggest complaint for now, but the added difficulty will make me a monster in the arena when they fix it.  I've learned to dodge plants as well as people in order to survive.  I can spot a dot from a click away.

When I first joined *The Quinfall* universe, what impressed me most were its stunning graphics and massive open world. As I progressed, discovering new regions and creatures kept amazing me. The ship interactions, ocean and sea physics, the way your character‚Äôs hair moves with the wind, and the beautifully crafted four-season system that even affects your character ‚Äî everything is incredibly well thought out.

It‚Äôs not pay-to-win, which I absolutely love. You can just grab small red packages for a modest monthly cost if you want to save some time. It‚Äôs a true MMO experience where you can enjoy looting, crafting, and taking part in different events with your friends in a vast, living world.

Definitely a game I‚Äôd recommend to anyone looking to unwind and escape daily stress for a while. I‚Äôve spent countless hours playing it, and I‚Äôll keep playing for many more.

Huge thanks to *The Quinfall* family and dev team for creating such an amazing experience.
Special thanks to R****** <3

Maybe in the game you can get something like headgear which is ears and it covers your human ears im not sure, my PC couldnt run the game and unfortunately i had to refund, which sucked cos i was looking forward to playing an MMORPG, i havent played one in years and years. If in the future i get a new PC i will 100% purchase the game again, but i'd definitely like to see an option to make the female jaw not so wide and heavy looking, and to see options for ears like rabbit and elf specifically that would be great. the 113 minutes playtime i have is purely customisation of my character, so as you can imagine 2hours in character creation, its quite the fun creation

This game is actually quite good! I bought the game at launch and played for a month or so, took a break for a bit and came back a little while ago and I have seen HUGE improvements in the game! It is one of the largest game worlds I think that I've ever seen, and it's FULL of content and things to explore! Open world bosses to conquer, open world dungeons, instanced dungeons, treasure chests scattered all throughout the world to find as well as treasure rooms with even more loot, TONS of professions and trade skills to master, in depth and intricate crafting system, and even the potential to build a home!! This game is LOADED with things to do, and TONS of different ways to play and enjoy the game! Very active and engaging community as well! The PVP in this game is also fantastic! There's open world PVP to be had as well as actual PVP matches like capture the flag, conquest, kill count, etc. This game is not developed by a huge team/studio, and yet even still, they have managed to create a VERY lively game world to explore in one of the most difficult genres to create a game within! On top of all of that, they are INCREDIBLY engaging with their player base and the community in regards to bug notices, suggestions, complaints, Q&A, and anything else! Many of the updated changes that have come to the game ever since launch have in fact been suggestions made by the very player base! This game deserves recognition, and this game has IMMENSE potential in becoming something even more magical and amazing than it already is now in early access! I don't write reviews very often, but this game TRULY deserves the positive feedback, as it has certainly earned that feedback in my eyes. This game has SO much to see and do and explore and adventure, that you will NEVER find yourself with nothing to do. It reminds me a lot of OSRS (Old School Runescape) in the way there are so many different trade skills and professions to master and level up, but modernized with better graphics and MUCH more engaging combat! Speaking of which, the combat is fantastic as well! It is a fantastic blend of action combat with tab targeting in regards to using spells from your hotbar while also "auto attacking" (holding left click). The game is so full of content and things to do, and they're just getting started! I think I'll be here for a while, and I greatly look forward to the future of The Quinfall ^_^

The Qunifall plays like a MMO of old. There are huge grinds to achieve the goals of progress. In some cases, it might not be for the feint of heart. However, if you are willing to put in the time to progress, what you will find in this game is a community of players, devs, and community service managers willing to help you if you reach out to them and put forth the effort on your own. It doesn't mean your ever request will be granted by any of them, but my experience has been great. If you are polite and try, eventually someone will answer those questions, help you level, group up with you, and invite you to their clan. Technically speaking our group is small, and we haven't went out of our way to interact outside of our current clan and small group of friends. What I can say, is the few times I have, it was certainly met with kind, helpful individuals. Like any game in today's world, I suspect you'll encounter the occasional troll, but there is really no avoiding that. I have watched the devs and their community service listen to the player base, I've also had amazing experiences with the few times I've needed to put in a ticket on their discord for in game issues. The Quinfall reminds me so much of the challenge, grind, and community I missed so much from my early days of playing EverQuest. Several of our group have really been enjoying what The Quinfall has to offer, and I am certainly looking forward to watching it grow and what other changes, challenges, and adventures it might have to offer.

As of 10/18/25, I've only played Quinfall for almost 5 hours.
I have to say that despite how much grief this game has gotten - which is pretty valid since this game has some bugs, glitches, and issues that need addressing - it's still a pretty decent game overall.

The combat system is great. It's very modern and up to date with some of the combat moves I've seen in other games recently.
However, it doesn't feel smooth or realistic. The turning is too fast, sudden, and janky. The lock-on system isn't 100% accurate and some of the attacks for the dual-wield axes need some work or at least not feel so Black Desert Online in design.
Maybe if the developers look towards Assassin's Creed Valhalla and Guild Wars 2 for inspiration on that, it would maybe be better in the long run.
The gathering of resources is great, there's some glitching with the tree meshes and textures when they transition from 3 dots to 2 dots. But i'm not sure if this is just me or something else entirely.
I'm not sure if we can use the resources we gather to build our very own house or claim a territory like we can in Once Human. But if we can, that would be fantastic since I love resource gathering and building when i can and if's an option.
Another thing that I would like to see is possibly some voice acting. At least for the major quest-giving NPC's and maybe our player character making comments/observations of the world as they explore it. Full-fledged cutscenes? No. For that, i will play my BioWare and Witcher games and call it done.

My number one pet peeve about this game is this - the textures and meshes are not optimized as well as they should be. And there are some graphical assets that need adjusting to make it easier for those on lower-end PC's to possibly play the game too.
I'm not saying this to be whiny or anything. My desktop gaming PC meets the minimum and recommended specs for Quinfall and yet I'm only getting an average of 20FPS *maximum* in *ALL* areas of the starter zone so far at level 29. And that is been a problem for me on medium, high, ultra, and epic graphical settings.
For those who are curious about my specs:
AMD Ryzen 7 8700F 8-Core Processor (4.10 GHz)
Nvidia Geforce RTX 5090 Ti (8GB vram) graphics card
16GB DDR5 RAM
1920x1080 native resolution via TV screen w/VSync turned on
If the devs can do what they can with the engine they're using to fully optimize their textures, meshes, and everything else, that would be fantastic. Because I should not be getting only 20FPS when I should be getting at least twice that while playing the game.

Despite my own personal issues with my game/playthrough, Quinfall has a lot of potential to be a great MMORPG or multplayer game in general.
It's still in it's early access phase, so there is a lot of room for improvement until the devs are confident and comfortable enough to release Quinfall in it's 100% entirety.
I'm leaving this as a thumb's up for now because of that. and I hope that this review helps any others that are looking to play Quinfall for the first time like myself :).

I do not recommend this game, and here‚Äôs why.

First off, the game looks good, but it‚Äôs very copy paste. Huge open landscapes with nothing really going on. Monsters only exist in camps, which you get sent to on missions. Outside of that, there‚Äôs basically nothing, and crafting is a massive grind.

Animals outside of camps only exist for skinning. They give no loot, no XP, so they‚Äôre just filler. Monsters that are 7‚Äì8 levels below you also give no XP and no loot, which forces you to only fight tougher monsters at your own level. That would be fine if combat and progression were balanced, but it‚Äôs not, you end up leveling, falling behind on gear, and constantly playing catch up.

Then there‚Äôs PvP, which is already broken. There are cash shop upgrade items that can pump weapons to nearly 700% base damage. That‚Äôs killed PvP completely. Melee can‚Äôt do anything while ranged players just run away and spam animations.

Travel is another pain point. Teleporting around the map is ridiculously expensive. Any gold you earn just gets chewed up on travel. There‚Äôs no cheaper city to city option,just one flat high cost. On top of that, warehouses/banks aren‚Äôt connected between towns, so you‚Äôre stuck paying even more just to move your stuff around constantly.

The game definitely has potential, but in its current Early Access state, it‚Äôs nowhere near there. Even at $2, I‚Äôd say pass. Oh, and character creation? Pretty lackluster.

P.S  their discord mod thinks he is royalty in his own kingdom. Condescending and really a bad show for their team. Horrible. Game is made to be played as somewhat large parties, but there's no playerbase.

I was actually going to add a positive review with a recommendation. This game looks a bit like a mix of BDO and New World, but it looked like the devs were doing everything right, that New World was doing wrong. This game did have the potential to be what New World promised; a modern MMO for everybody who enjoys a good MMORPG. And, it appeared that the devs followed the success formula of Black Desert Online and Albion Online and offer so many things to do, that you must pick a few to get good at or suck at everything.

It is early access, but after the latest couple of updates it is becoming apparent that the devs have lost focus on what made this project very promising for everybody who enjoys a good MMORPG to begin with. 

The devs listen too much to the very vocal minority of the gear-vs-gear end-game crowd and I am afraid that Quinfall is on the same path down the toilet as New World. 

Just like New World, the concept of Quinfall was sold as being a sandbox for everybody. Right now, the focus is exclusively on the corner with the gear-vs-gear players, who cry if there are not enough plastic shovels, sieves, and buckets for them to be constantly entertained (read new dungeons, better gear drops, more trinkets and glitter, higher level ceilings, expansions, and more, more, more).

The game has been in early access for 8 months and the tables with profession rankings show that there should be plenty of skilled crafters for a healthy supply of both mid and high level gear on the auction house. Yet, there is not. Either those who reached level 70 (before the patch) did so as a means to their gear-vs-gear end-game or they burned out and left the game. Those of us life-skillers grinding away at the crafting skills did not provide that gear, because we were not yet able to. The solution? Drops of high level gear to satisfy the gear-vs-gear players, which was a slap in the face for those of us who wasted our time on crafting professions. So, the devs fixed the wrong hole and created another to bleed players.

In addition to making crafting pointless, the gear drops can be recycled and you get high-level materials, so no point in being a gatherer either. The game is still early access and they have already increased the max character level! Pretty soon, you will be able to start a new character at level 100; then you just have to grind a few levels before you can start spending money on enhancing your end-game gear drops.

Such a sad waste of potential.

I gave this game a fair chance, but it sucks and is boring. The models that you can choose from for your character look like crap and there isn't much room for customization except war paint and tattoos. The graphics of the game look horrible. I had to change the contrast to -30 just to get it to not hurt my eyes. The tutorial was stupid. It had you choose weapons and get skill books for weapons before it had you test out all the weapons on the dummies. So I ended up getting Level 5 weapons and skill books for weapons that I found out that I did not want to use. There is no way to switch weapon sets. I wanted to soften and snipe enemies from the distance with a bow or mage staff and then do melee close up. But there is no hotkey to switch weapon sets. I had to open up the inventory and manually select the other weapon. But then I got a popup window that I could not close warning me that I can't use skills for over 1.5 minutes. And since I could not close the popup window in time, I kept taking damage from the enemy and almost died. I was considering switching weapons anyway and not using skills, but even after the 100th time of seeing that warning, it still forcing the popup window on you so it is impossible. You level up on weapons that you use. So if you waste time using the wrong weapon like I did, you will always waste skill points on that weapon. I finally decided on dual wielding axes, but then I got a quest that was supposed to give both daggers and axes. I took it, but it was like a one handed axe or hammer or something so it was a wasted quest. So here I was stuck with Level 1 axes or I could switch to Level 5 daggers but then all my experience would go onto my daggers. Okay, fine. Let's just forget about all of that. In the starter town, there are some enemies not too far. There was a rift and it was boring because it was just 20 or so enemies standing close together and you run up to them and try to kill the ones on the edges without aggroing the rest of them. But a few seconds after you kill one, they just respawn again. Which make the game really repetitive, low effort, and boring. And there was a training area with some orcs or something. I forgot what they were. They just stand really still so you can walk up to them and they won't attack you, even if you kill their friend right next to them. But then I had to go to the next town called Meadow and it was even worse. It was just a boring town with houses and nothing to do. I ran outside the town like 5 miles in every direction, and there was nothing but trees and grass and animals. And a couple of boring player farm houses. No enemies. No danger. Nothing. There literally is nothing good about this game. It is not even worth the $2 that I paid for it.

I do not recommend this game, and here‚Äôs why.

First off, the game looks good, but it‚Äôs very copy paste. Huge open landscapes with nothing really going on. Monsters only exist in camps, which you get sent to on missions. Outside of that, there‚Äôs basically nothing, and crafting is a massive grind.

Animals outside of camps only exist for skinning. They give no loot, no XP, so they‚Äôre just filler. Monsters that are 7‚Äì8 levels below you also give no XP and no loot, which forces you to only fight tougher monsters at your own level. That would be fine if combat and progression were balanced, but it‚Äôs not, you end up leveling, falling behind on gear, and constantly playing catch up.

Then there‚Äôs PvP, which is already broken. There are cash shop upgrade items that can pump weapons to nearly 700% base damage. That‚Äôs killed PvP completely. Melee can‚Äôt do anything while ranged players just run away and spam animations.

Travel is another pain point. Teleporting around the map is ridiculously expensive. Any gold you earn just gets chewed up on travel. There‚Äôs no cheaper city to city option,just one flat high cost. On top of that, warehouses/banks aren‚Äôt connected between towns, so you‚Äôre stuck paying even more just to move your stuff around constantly.

The game definitely has potential, but in its current Early Access state, it‚Äôs nowhere near there. Even at $2, I‚Äôd say pass. Oh, and character creation? Pretty lackluster.

P.S  their discord mod thinks he is royalty in his own kingdom. Condescending and really a bad show for their team. Horrible. Game is made to be played as somewhat large parties, but there's no playerbase.

I was actually going to add a positive review with a recommendation. This game looks a bit like a mix of BDO and New World, but it looked like the devs were doing everything right, that New World was doing wrong. This game did have the potential to be what New World promised; a modern MMO for everybody who enjoys a good MMORPG. And, it appeared that the devs followed the success formula of Black Desert Online and Albion Online and offer so many things to do, that you must pick a few to get good at or suck at everything.

It is early access, but after the latest couple of updates it is becoming apparent that the devs have lost focus on what made this project very promising for everybody who enjoys a good MMORPG to begin with. 

The devs listen too much to the very vocal minority of the gear-vs-gear end-game crowd and I am afraid that Quinfall is on the same path down the toilet as New World. 

Just like New World, the concept of Quinfall was sold as being a sandbox for everybody. Right now, the focus is exclusively on the corner with the gear-vs-gear players, who cry if there are not enough plastic shovels, sieves, and buckets for them to be constantly entertained (read new dungeons, better gear drops, more trinkets and glitter, higher level ceilings, expansions, and more, more, more).

The game has been in early access for 8 months and the tables with profession rankings show that there should be plenty of skilled crafters for a healthy supply of both mid and high level gear on the auction house. Yet, there is not. Either those who reached level 70 (before the patch) did so as a means to their gear-vs-gear end-game or they burned out and left the game. Those of us life-skillers grinding away at the crafting skills did not provide that gear, because we were not yet able to. The solution? Drops of high level gear to satisfy the gear-vs-gear players, which was a slap in the face for those of us who wasted our time on crafting professions. So, the devs fixed the wrong hole and created another to bleed players.

In addition to making crafting pointless, the gear drops can be recycled and you get high-level materials, so no point in being a gatherer either. The game is still early access and they have already increased the max character level! Pretty soon, you will be able to start a new character at level 100; then you just have to grind a few levels before you can start spending money on enhancing your end-game gear drops.

Such a sad waste of potential.

I came into The Quinfall really hoping to have fun, but honestly, it ended up being pretty disappointing. The game looks like it has potential, but actually playing it is a different story.

Performance is rough. I‚Äôve got decent hardware, and the game still stutters constantly. Lag spikes, rubber-banding, random disconnects ‚Äî all of it makes combat and exploration feel annoying instead of exciting. Half the time it feels like I‚Äôm fighting the game itself, not the enemies.

The world is big, sure, but it doesn‚Äôt feel alive. A lot of the areas just look the same, NPCs barely react to anything, and the quests are basically ‚Äúgo here, kill that, collect this‚Äù on repeat. It gets old really fast.

Combat needs a lot of work too. The animations are slow and don‚Äôt line up with hits, and abilities just don‚Äôt feel satisfying. Either enemies melt instantly or suddenly chunk your health in one hit ‚Äî there‚Äôs barely any middle ground. It just comes off as clunky and unbalanced.

And honestly, the community side doesn‚Äôt help either. From my experience, the GMs and staff on Discord can be pretty harsh. It sometimes feels like if you ask the wrong question or give any criticism, you can get warned or muted out of nowhere. It gives off a vibe that you‚Äôre not really welcome unless you‚Äôre just praising the game.

On top of everything, the UI feels messy, menus are awkward, and a lot of systems seem half-finished. It just doesn‚Äôt feel ready yet.

Very grindy with QoL (like more inventory space) locked behind a paywall. And you'll need a lot of space if you want to level all the crafting skills.

Started as a "mage"(staff user, no classes but weapons determin the skills you can use) and it feels very underwhelming. I usually just use heavy attack since it does more damage than my spells. Slow cooldowns and high mana cost don't make it more enjoyable... Combat feel weird as well, not helped by the over the shoulder view. As a ranged player, I need to look down to hit enemies that are standing next to me or I'll shoot over them.

Tried healer (life staff) for a bit and wanted to run around and help people but since your spells don't effect them unless you're in a party together I dropped it.

QoL features like crafting from storage, a search/filter option when crafting or looking in your bank (bank doesn't have a sort function either), or a pop-up of how many items you have total when you hover over it or want to turn it in for rewards are highly needed as well.

If you want buy this "Game", buy only when it will be discount. Its not whorth the cost. Devs is promise that all be fine and fix all, but that will not happen because they goal is get fast money, nothing more... sad...

Do you want to play an uglier, completely worse feeling version of New World?  If so then my first question is, "What si wrong with you?" and my second statement would be, "then this pile of crap is perfect for you".  Even at $1.99, I don't know if there is much here to offer.  It's boring, directionless; completely unpolished and just not worth supporting.
the combat really needs work, attacks go past the enemy and there is no lock to anyone you choose to fight, the camera shakes due to character movement during combat with the camera shake turned off.

Given that the game is early access and I was able to get it for relatively cheap on-sale I would say I got what I paid for.  Game has a lot of future potential but given the current state of things be prepared to struggle solo in the early game especially with certain classes. Combat and Crafting don't seem to match the leveling experience yet and most of the interesting gameplay or challenges will require you to group up which isnt always easy to do early on.  That being said if you can look past the rough edges and spend alot of time grinding Experience on crafting and gathering then you might find yourself with a lot to do as both are very expansive in the game.
